entry.title: Jupyter notebook test
entry.content:
Preparing cochlear hair cell count data for analysis

Data

MyoVIIa-labeled explants are imaged twice: once at the apical region, and once at the basal region of the coil.

From those images, we manually count the number of outer and inner hair cells within the sampling region.

The data for six untreated cultures might look like this:

APICAL cA1 cA2 cA3 cA4 cA5 cA6 cA7 cA8
inner HC 20 18 20 12 18 17 17 18
outer HC 65 52 73 45 53 52 55 56
CONTROL TOTAL 85 70 93 57 71 69 72 74
BASAL cB1 cB2 cB3 cB4 cB5 cB6 cB7 cB8
inner HC 18 17 20 16 19 19 18 17
outer HC 63 55 77 50 57 60 63 55
CONTROL TOTAL 81 72 97 66 76 79 81 72

Letâ€™s work with the total number of hair cells (inner HC + outer HC) in the basal coil.

Descriptive statistics

We would like to compare two groups: one which has been treated with gentamicin, and an untreated control.

Our data is stored as rows in a CSV, and looks like this:

        controlT,81,72,97,66,76,79,81,72
        gentT,24,13,10,12,12,27,29,28 ### Process
  1. Load packages
  2. Transfer the data from an external file to a dataframe
  3. Transpose the dataframe
    4. #### Load packages ```python import pandas as pd # a library for data manipulation and analysis import numpy as np # a library for operating on arrays and matrices import matplotlib.pyplot as plt # a matplotlib module used to create plots import scipy.stats as stats # a SciPy module containing probability functions and statistical functions import seaborn as sns # another plotting library ``` #### Read the CSV into a dataframe, transpose values ```python # read the CSV into dataframe df and print df = pd.read_csv('gent.csv', header=None, index_col=0) # no header in csv, use the first column as row label df ```
    1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8
    0
    Control 81 72 97 66 76 79 81 72
    + Gentamicin 24 13 10 12 12 27 29 28
    ```python # transpose df and print dfx = df.T dfx ```
    Control + Gentamicin
    1 81 24
    2 72 13
    3 97 10
    4 66 12
    5 76 12
    6 79 27
    7 81 29
    8 72 28
    #### Calculate descriptive statistics ```python # adjust precision pd.set_option("display.precision",2) # calculate column statistics and print dfx_stats=dfx.describe() dfx_stats ```
    Control + Gentamicin
    count 8.00 8.00
    mean 78.00 19.38
    std 9.26 8.31
    min 66.00 10.00
    25% 72.00 12.00
    50% 77.50 18.50
    75% 81.00 27.25
    max 97.00 29.00
    We see that the mean of the two groups is quite difference, but that the groups have similar variance. #### Generate a box-and-whisker plot with an overlying swarmplot ```python ax = sns.boxplot(data=dfx, whis=np.inf, palette="mako") # box-and-whisker plot with mako color palette ax = sns.swarmplot(data=dfx, color=".2") ax.set_title('Gentamicin is toxic to hair cells') # x axis title ax.set_xlabel('Treatment') ax.set_ylabel('Number of hair cells') # y axis title ``` Text(0, 0.5, 'Number of hair cells') ![png](output_11_1.png) ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ``` ```python ```
entry.summary: Preparing cochlear hair cell count data for analysis

entry.title: Jupyter notebook test
entry.content:
Jupyter notebook test

Descriptive statistics

Preparing cochlear hair cell count data for analysis¶

Data¶

MyoVIIa-labeled explants are imaged twice: once at the apical region, and once at the basal region of the coil.

From those images, we manually count the number of outer and inner hair cells within the sampling region.

The data for six untreated cultures might look like this:

APICAL cA1 cA2 cA3 cA4 cA5 cA6 cA7 cA8
inner HC 20 18 20 12 18 17 17 18
outer HC 65 52 73 45 53 52 55 56
CONTROL TOTAL 85 70 93 57 71 69 72 74
BASAL cB1 cB2 cB3 cB4 cB5 cB6 cB7 cB8
inner HC 18 17 20 16 19 19 18 17
outer HC 63 55 77 50 57 60 63 55
CONTROL TOTAL 81 72 97 66 76 79 81 72

Let's work with the total number of hair cells (inner HC + outer HC) in the basal coil.

Descriptive statistics¶

We would like to compare two groups: one which has been treated with gentamicin, and an untreated control.

Our data is stored as rows in a CSV, and looks like this:

        controlT,81,72,97,66,76,79,81,72
    gentT,24,13,10,12,12,27,29,28

Process¶

    </p>
  1. Load packages
  2. Transfer the data from an external file to a dataframe
  3. Transpose the dataframe
    4. </div> </div>

    Load packages¶

    In [12]:
    import pandas as pd               # a library for data manipulation and analysis
import numpy as np                # a library for operating on arrays and matrices
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt   # a matplotlib module used to create plots
import scipy.stats as stats       # a SciPy module containing probability functions and statistical functions
import seaborn as sns             # another plotting library

    Read the CSV into a dataframe, transpose values¶

    In [105]:
    # read the CSV into dataframe df and print
df = pd.read_csv('gent.csv', header=None, index_col=0)      # no header in csv, use the first column as row label
df
    Out[105]:
    1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8
    0
    Control 81 72 97 66 76 79 81 72
    + Gentamicin 24 13 10 12 12 27 29 28
    In [130]:
    # transpose df and print
dfx = df.T
dfx
    Out[130]:
    Control + Gentamicin
    1 81 24
    2 72 13
    3 97 10
    4 66 12
    5 76 12
    6 79 27
    7 81 29
    8 72 28

    Calculate descriptive statistics¶

    In [131]:
    # adjust precision
pd.set_option("display.precision",2)

# calculate column statistics and print
dfx_stats=dfx.describe()
dfx_stats
    Out[131]:
    Control + Gentamicin
    count 8.00 8.00
    mean 78.00 19.38
    std 9.26 8.31
    min 66.00 10.00
    25% 72.00 12.00
    50% 77.50 18.50
    75% 81.00 27.25
    max 97.00 29.00

    We see that the mean of the two groups is quite difference, but that the groups have similar variance.

    Generate a box-and-whisker plot with an overlying swarmplot¶

    In [132]:
    ax = sns.boxplot(data=dfx, whis=np.inf, palette="mako")   # box-and-whisker plot with mako color palette
ax = sns.swarmplot(data=dfx, color=".2")
ax.set_title('Gentamicin is toxic to hair cells')          # x axis title
ax.set_xlabel('Treatment')
ax.set_ylabel('Number of hair cells')                      # y axis title
    Out[132]:
    Text(0, 0.5, 'Number of hair cells')
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    In [ ]:
    (missing reference)

entry.title: Topics in statistics and experimental design

link.title: Topics in statistics and experimental design

entry.content:
This is a list of statistical method walk-throughs and thoughts on experimental design that Iâ€™d like to write up. I intend to work through examples in Jupyter notebook, using data from my own experiments.

Cochlear cultures hair cell counts

Â Â  - Experimental design and quantification
Â Â  - Statistical power and power analysis
Â Â  - Descriptive statistics
Â Â  - Hypothesis testing
Â Â  - Detection of outliers

Zebrafish lateral line hair cell counts

Â Â  - Experimental design and quantification
Â Â  - Statistical power and power analysis
Â Â  - Dose-response curve analysis

Hair cell imaging

Â Â  - Labels and cell death
Â Â  - Live imaging

Gene expression in mouse branchial arch tissue

Â Â  - Statistical power and power analysis
Â Â  - Hypothesis testing

Landmark-based morphometrics

Â Â  - Statistical power and power analysis
Â Â  - PCA

Use jupyter nbconvert 210227-descriptive-statistics.ipynb â€“to html to convert notebook to markdown

I intend to work through examples in Jupyter notebook, using data from my own experiments. Cochlear cultures hair cell counts Â Â - Experimental design and quantification Â Â - Statistical power and power analysis Â Â - Descriptive statistics Â Â - Hypothesis testing Â Â - Detection of outliers Zebrafish lateral line hair cell counts Â Â - Experimental design and quantification Â Â - Statistical power and power analysis Â Â - Dose-response curve analysis Hair cell imaging Â Â - Labels and cell death Â Â - Live imaging Gene expression in mouse branchial arch tissue Â Â - Statistical power and power analysis Â Â - Hypothesis testing Landmark-based morphometrics Â Â - Statistical power and power analysis Â Â - PCA
